1067532291520499712.text:
The ‘ETHFinger Attack’ - @ericsson_axel 

Become Fort Knox:
- Have lots of ETH 
- Run a validator
- Stake 5% of your ETH
- Advertise v good terms
- Attract lots of delegators

Nuke yourself:
- Intentionally get slashed

Deflates ETH supply & increases value of your remaining ETHpic.twitter.com/SV5mXt637w

1024146656197898240.text: (8) Examples include: massive public lotteries, elections, and open markets for digital services. End!

1024146655384223744.text: (7) Therefore, a set of applications that make sense for public blockchains: Applications with 2 or more participants who need provable-state and cannot trust a single machine to append and store the state.

1024146654688030720.text: (6) Open storage enables many machines to store the full past and current state of the computer, meaning no single machine can withhold data (proofs) from you.

1024146654037868546.text: (5) b. Anyone can be a miner, and anyone can run a node. This means anyone can append to the state of the computer, and anyone can store the state. Open mining ensures that it is very hard to censor pending state changes (50%<hashpower needed in nakamoto consensus for this).

1024146653287051265.text: (4) Issue: the remote machine has full control over which state changes are considered (i.e. can censor transactions) and can withhold proofs at will. Now, we add the second property:

1024146652385300480.text: 3) Merkle Computers are useful when we want to be convinced something happened on a remote machine. Example: I voted in the online election, but can I please have a proof that my vote was tallied.

1024146651705831425.text: (2) a. Merkle Computer. A computer where the root hash of a merkle tree commits to all past state changes and their ordering. If the root is known by an observer, a prover can convince the observer whether a state change happened at a specific time using a simple merkle proof.

1024146650774745089.text: (1) What applications make sense to run on a public blockchain? We can answer this by looking at two key properties of public blockchains:

1023660640383029249.text: Consensus about what happened in the past or what should be done in the future is one of the most expensive human games/processes. Not surprising open consensus protocols require massive amounts of power spent (pow) or massive capital lockups (pos)

986498214760103936.text: Needed: open source library for using OpenSSL crypto primitives in browser using Emscripten C->wasm compilation. Random javascript crypto libraries < vetted and battle tested OpenSSL C. One codebase for critical code

986019681982181376.text: On USD/Real Asset backed tokens: Issuers (banks, federal reserve) need to choose which fork to guarantee withdrawals from. In case of contentious hard fork, issuer ends up having disproportionate power over canonicality without holding ETH, Staking, or being active in community

981089509084299265.text: But I will happily support anyone with smart ideas to address these issues with funds and outreach - please reach out. End!

981088126562025472.text: Many tricky steps to get there: usable client side wallet software, multisig standards, actual widespread usage of public/private key crypto, apps designed like merkle computers (state changes commit to their own ordering & allow provable statements about current state).

981086443790413824.text: From a UX perspective, we are not even close to done in crypto until I can use signatures from my private key to interact with all these systems, and clearly see and track state changes in remote system based on their hash.

981086214852788224.text: All of this can be, and should be a seamless 1-click or n-click experience (maximally low n) with no redundant or extraneous data inputs.

981085627071414272.text: 3. Sign up from scratch to get utilities - internet, electricity, gas - using the utility company’s website

981085509412732928.text: 2. Use an off-brand credit/debit card payment processor (randomly fails, double charges, who stores my #?).

981085377741037569.text: 1. Get health insurance (broken signups, forces multiple accounts for different actions, info gets lost).

Blockchain/Merkle Computer design paradigms can massively improve UX in legacy web applications.
